p: Research has reported that seasonal cyclicity is a ubiquitous feature of acute infectious diseases, which is also commonly observed in respiratory viral diseases ( Martinez, 2018). For instance, influenza outbreaks occur every winter in temperate regions ( Shaman et al., 2010). An epidemiological model in the United States indicated that absolute humidity affected the seasonality of influenza incidence ( Shaman et al., 2010). Moreover, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) broke out in China in mid-November 2002, and had almost entirely resolved by July 2003 ( Tan et al., 2005; Ma et al., 2020). A study in China that was based on case studies in Hong Kong, Guangzhou, Beijing, and Taiyuan indicated that the outbreaks of SARS were significantly associated with variations in temperature ( Tan et al., 2005).
